column4: Does anyone know how to require a password to read and edit the .bash_history file?
you can use setattr (i think) to make the file append only
Can you explain further?

the attribute makes it so the file can't be edited or deleted or altered, except by appending more data to it. it requires root to change the attribute. it would help if you explained why you want it password protected
I wish for it to password protected as I may accidentally type my sudo password in plain text
... that's a pretty horrible reason to go through the extreme trouble of protecting it
What other solutions do I have?
because that's what it is, a LOT of trouble to go through. it's far better to just simply not type your password on the commandline :)
if you're under the impression that the password prompt from sudo saves your password, you're mistaken. it does not.
I agree, but it does happen occasionally by accident
then rm ~/.bash_history if it happens. your only other feasible option is to encrypt your home directory
I know it doesn't save my password, but that's if you input it at the right time XD
do other people use the computer in question?
as in, do they remotely log in and don't have physical access?
Thank you, haha. And no, no one else uses my computer. I'm just paranoid.
then yeah, you're wasting your time. nobody can get to that file without already being root..
I'm not root, but I can access it :|
because you own it.
I have a lot to learn. Thank you, though :)
no problem. now go learn about RAID recovery and then you can help me :D
Will do! Bye, and thanks again!
